Stuyvesant Student Body Expresses Jealousy in Wake of Bronx Science Scandal

April 1, 2013

Humor

Stuyvesant Student Body Expresses Jealousy in Wake of Bronx Science Scandal

By WILLIAM CHANG ⋅ April 1, 2013 ⋅ Post a comment

Earlier this month, a track team scandal at the Bronx High School of Science shook the media and left many questions unanswered in the New York public school community. How could officials have let this happen? What could have caused such vulgar behavior? And why can’t Stuy do better? Many of Stuyvesant’s team captains have spoken out regarding the competition and have made resolutions to harass their rookie players in hopes of gaining an edge over Bronx Science.

Many of Stuyvesant’s major athletic teams have already taken a stand to make the school the best it can be in the worst way possible. The Running Rebels, led by junior co-captain Matthew Dalton, will be stepping up their locker room game, as will the wrestling team. “The freshmen will need to make some sacrifices, and it won’t be easy for us,” said senior and co-captain Matt Moy. “But being a Spartan means putting the team on your back, or vice-versa when the time comes.” The room, packed with large, sweaty teenagers, roared with approval as reporters were quickly ushered out and the doors barred from the inside.

Coaches also seem to be in support of this newfound bonding technique. “It’s great to see young people showing interest and initiative in ways like this, going the extra mile,” said varsity football coach Mark Strasser. “When I was playing in college, my coach told me that it’s what you do when nobody’s watching that really defines you. This technique helped me create lasting bonds with countless numbers of teammates throughout the years.”

Critics of this newfound approach call it “rude” and “ungentlemanly.” One such critic, junior and fencing star Philip Shin, said that the culprits “should at least take the freshmen out to a nice dinner first. How do they know if they’re right for each other anyway? Here on the fencing team, we like to take our initiation process slowly,” Shin said. Freshman team member Aaron Choi declined to comment and instead hid in the corner, sobbing quietly.

When asked whether he was taking the rivalry towards Bronx Science a bit too far (and breaking every rule and moral boundary that applies to a high school athlete), Moy rebutted, “It’s alright; the wrestling team is no stranger to close, intimate, one-on-one contact. In addition to that, we also wrestle.”

The teams have been under a lot of pressure recently to boost school spirit, and this is simply one attempt at achieving that greater cause. Still, many doubt that the school-wide hazing wave will be enough. Some have even suggested unifying all the school’s teams under one name, though that idea was quickly shot down by athletes, non-athletes, coaches, faculty, sports spectators, family members, janitorial staff, pedestrians, and members of Congress. As such, it seems the only hope for school spirit is, once again, thrashing Bronx Science, and so it looks like harassment is here to stay.

Many members of the administration are optimistic about the new practice. “I came to work at Stuyvesant because it is the best,” said Principal Jie Zhang. “And our track record proves our superiority, whether it comes to bathroom fires or cheating scandals. It’s only right for us to be better than Bronx Science at harassment too.”

Discussion

11 comments for “Stuyvesant Student Body Expresses Jealousy in Wake of Bronx Science Scandal”

  1. I don’t think this is funny. There are some things you don’t make fun of. Sexual assault is one of those things.

    Posted by Emma Lesser | April 1, 2013, 9:34 pm
    Reply to this comment

  2. This parody is disgusting, not funny, and completely inappropriate for a school newspaper.
    The first thing William Chang does in his article is trivialize hazing and sexual assault. He makes the traumatic hazing of a Bronx Science track athlete the setting for his joke. Even the way he extends the joke is terrible — Chang implicitly identifies the “taboo” element of hazing and sexual assault in sports as homosexuality. Not only has Chang cast aforementioned (and thus all) sexual assault as a laughing matter, but also pinpointed homosexuality as the source of the hilarity and wrongness.

    It makes me pretty sad that people thought it was okay to publish an article with the line “[...] Choi declined to comment and instead hid in the corner, sobbing quietly.”

    Posted by Isaac Lapides | April 2, 2013, 4:08 am
    Reply to this comment

  3. I understand that this is supposed to be a HUMOR section piece, but its absurd to use sexual assault as a “joke.” These students were humiliated and just the crude nature of stuy students or anyone being “jealous” of that is horrible, even on a fictional level.

    But since we’re on the topic, you know what else would be funny to post on- cancer. It’s in good taste these days, ya know?

    Posted by Pria Islam | April 9, 2013, 8:45 pm
    Reply to this comment

  4. Did you think this was going to be well-received?

    Posted by The Arsonist | April 9, 2013, 8:46 pm
    Reply to this comment

  5. For much of this year, I’ve been impressed over and over again at the incredible journalism happening at the Spectator. As an alumna, it makes me proud to know that the students of Stuyvesant are pushing harder and harder on the administration through investigative journalism, op-eds, and humor pieces. This piece, however, left me incredibly disappointed. As someone who has personally faced sexual harassment, I know that it is never a laughing matter. The perpetuation of rape culture and homophobia has got to end and this kind of humor works exactly against that. I sincerely hope the Spectator editors will address this and do better in the future.

    Posted by Sophia Abbot | April 9, 2013, 9:01 pm
    Reply to this comment

  6. You’ve got to be kidding me. This isn’t just unfunny, it’s offensive on numerous levels, and completely inappropriate in every way.

    I expected a lot better of the Spectator. Really, trivializing sexual assault? Really?

    Posted by Aleksandra Burshteyn | April 9, 2013, 9:10 pm
    Reply to this comment

  7. Isaac summed it up perfectly.

    This is tasteless and offensive. How anyone thought it would be a good move to write about the incident in such a light is beyond me. It isn’t supportive of Bronx Science nor does it put Stuyvesant and its sports teams in good standing. This was one article better left unpublished.

    Posted by Catherine Hong | April 9, 2013, 10:28 pm
    Reply to this comment

  8. I completely agree with Isaac’s comment.

    I know for a fact that the humor department gets censored by faculty, because I know for a fact that students writing for the humor department run into trouble when they write about specific teachers or administrators in the humor section. How did this slip by the all-important, censoring eye then, I would ask?

    I think that the humor section of the Spectator is one of the best things about it, but if it continues to put out drivel like this, it just becomes a hate-filled rag. Kind of like the NYPost!

    Interesting, though, that some administrators tend to keep an eye trained on the NYPost and the harm it may do to their own reputations (Or perhaps I am too cynical! All for the reputation of the school! Right?), but don’t examine fully the all-important publications at this school, and the ways in which they may be harmful to students.

    I don’t know Principal Zhang or her administrative practices, in fact, I wish her all the best! I imagine that she has a difficult job. But I am familiar with some of the other administrators at Stuyvesant, and I would ask that they take a good look at their own administrative policies when considering how to deal with issues like this. A free and open press is important, but not in a way that is potentially harmful to students.

    Posted by Emma Handte ('12) | April 9, 2013, 10:56 pm
    Reply to this comment

  9. Get a grip- it’s April 1st. Both schools have taken their knocks and no group of 3- 4,000 students is perfect. Laughing at yourself is the first step to healing, be it a cheating scandal or behavior ALLEGED to have been inappropraite (maybe we should wait for the investigation before we are so critical- anyone out there ever heard of the Duke Lacrosse team?). So y’all calm down and enjoy this fo what it is, a brilliant parody.

    Posted by Lorne Sheren (Stuy '69) | April 10, 2013, 11:13 pm
    Reply to this comment

    • I think Lorne is right.

      They’re merely poking fun at the “scandalous” culture of Stuy, whether it be about clothing, fires, or cheating, Stuy seems to always want to be in some sort of scandal.

      This isn’t trivializing sexual assault – it’s making fun of Stuy culture through current events. It’s crass, sure, but funny nonetheless.

      Posted by Anonymous | April 14, 2013, 7:54 pm
      Reply to this comment

  10. I honestly think that this piece was not in poor taste.

    The “victims” in the article here are not the butt of the joke. The Bronx Science students were not the butt of the joke.

    Just making the sexual assault the setting of the joke does not trivialize it; it just instead makes fun of Stuy’s extreme competition.

    It does not trivialize the assault that they suffered through. The over the type satire in the piece clearly does not condone rape.

    It’s a piece that is critical/joking of the competition that Bronx Science and Stuyvesant High School is known for (I remember those juvenile facebook groups…). It jokes around with wrestling as a sport and extreme school spirit. It plays with the countless NY Post controversies that Stuyvesant HS has experienced.

    The piece utilizes the current event as a vehicle for the joke. But it isn’t the sexual assault that is the joke.

    But then again, I’m of the belief that some rape jokes are okay. I know there are some people that do not believe that any rape jokes in any circumstances are funny. But I don’t think that’s fair. Humor can be used for good, to point out ironies and criticize things.
    There are obvious exceptions, but I think that this piece for April 1st isn’t too much, or “unfit for a school newspaper.”

    Posted by Jay | April 15, 2013, 4:04 am
    Reply to this comment
